channel.title: Used Car Price Prediction on
channel.description: Recent content in Used Car Price Prediction on

item.title: Introduction
item.description: Used Car Price Prediction # Project Objective: # Business Problem: # Asymmetric information, also known as â€œinformation failure,â€ takes place during a transaction where one party has greater material knowledge or better information than the other party.â€‹ â€œThe Market of Lemons: Quality Uncertainty and the Market Mechanism,â€ by George Akerlof Consumers face incompleteâ€‹ information on used cars. The imbalanced information between sellers and buyers give more power to sellers manipulating the prices and giving buyers uncomfortable buying position.

item.title: Data Collection
item.description: Dataset # Our dataset is taken from Kaggle public dataset (1.45 GB)â€‹. Based on resale car listings on Craigslistâ€‹, columns include selling price, car attributes, color, condition, VIN, mileage, make and model, etc.â€‹ We enhanced and imputed some data with data from iSeeCars. Used Car Dataset MSRP Dataset iSeeCar ğŸ‘‰ Since each listing data is 100% based on seller entry on Craiglist, there is high possibility sellers tend to input false data, resulting in datapoints that are anormal.

item.title: EDA
item.description: Explorative Data Analysis # Perforing EDA, we found a couple of interesting insights. Price against key features Price against several key variables:â€‹ # There seems to be a significant difference of price ranges between car manufacturers. However the range within each manufacturer seems very large. It is most possibly due to high number of different car models. That’s why we will not include manufacturer and model as predictors as they can be better represented by other more relevant variables.

item.title: Pre-modelling
item.description: Pre-modelling # Initial Outlier handling & filling in null valuesâ€‹ # Odometer: â€‹ # Highly right skewed â€‹ Outliers are removed: Upper threshold +7* stdevâ€‹ Condition: # Fill nulls based on odometerâ€‹ Newer condition has low odometer. Quantile <25% = Excellentâ€‹ Quantile 25%-50% = Goodâ€‹ Quantile >50% = Fairâ€‹ NA = Fairâ€‹ Transmission: â€‹ # drop NA rows (~0.6%)â€‹ Categorical variables: # Fill in NA with modeâ€‹ For cylinders, drive, type, fuelâ€‹ Fill NA with the most common types based on matched model andâ€‹ manufacturerâ€‹ Fill the rest of NA with modeâ€‹ Created Features: â€‹ # Color: 12 colors into binary column of “is_neutral"â€‹

item.title: Re-engineering
item.description: Post-modelling # Re-engineering # After running the base models with initially feature engineered dataset, we saw low performing results and then re-engineered. Contextual Anomaly Detection # Odometer: â€‹ # Standard car odometer should have max 300,000 miles.â€‹ Trimming data with 75th quantile + 3*IQR, ~268,000, as a cut reduced skewness from 3.04 to 0.3â€‹. Only new car should have 0 odometer so trimmed otherwiseâ€‹. Price:â€‹ # Dropped cars below $1000 and greater than $200,000 thatâ€‹ are in the extreme ranges not fit for our analysis purposeâ€‹ Max car price was three billion dollars â€‹ MSRP:â€‹ # MSRP is the manufacturer’s suggested retail price (list price) â€‹ Dropped MSRP < car price as MSRP should be higher thanâ€‹ used car selling priceâ€‹ Code Reference

item.title: Models
item.description: Models # Our goal is to predict the sale price of a used car, which is a supervised regression problem. We pick our models base on two considerations, flexibility (accuracy) and interpretability.â€‹ We value model accuracy over interpretability because:â€‹ The industry we are in doesnâ€™t require we provide explanation for the decision we make.â€‹ Features of our used car dataset are easy to understand, thus making it easy for us to debug the model even without high model interpretability.

item.title: Result
item.description: Model Results # Just like our expectation, Ensemble Tree methods, specifically XGBoost has the best overall performance. â€‹ This is not very surprising since ensemble method is known to:â€‹ Have higher predictive accuracy, compared to the individual models.â€‹ Be very useful when there is both linear and non-linear type of data in the datasetâ€‹ Linear Regression and Linear SVR, like expected, didnâ€™t perform well. From the R squared score, we see that both models could not capture all the variance of our data.
